description:
This is the best Tokyo Express location that I have been to.  Of the chain, I have been to 4 of them.  This one is clean and staff brings out the food quickly.

The food overall is not bad considering its semi fast  food.

Love the Chicken Teriyaki dinner... the only thing that was not too good was the  chicken was a bit cold... otherwise its not bad.
author: Jerry W.

description:
This place is ok... Sushi is ok.  I recently ordered the tempura soba and was a tad disappointed.  I've had it different places and I guess they serve it differently at Tokyo Express.

It's convenient and decent.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Desperate for sushi, I sought this place out.

Think of this like supermarket sushi with a seating area and free tea.

They have daily specials such as chicken teriyaki bowls and sushi specials, which will save you money.

If you're looking for authentic sushi this isn't your place.

If you're just desperate for sushi and you don't want to look for a Japanese food cart in the area, or pay a lot of money, then this is your place.

The roll was decent. The fish wasn't overly great, but it wasn't worm churning bad either.

Each meal comes with soup (salty) and overdressed salad.

Great for tourists, people who don't want to spend a lot, or those on the go--or all three.
author: Jack R.

description:
This place was just ok but leaning toward below average... I ordered the Vegetable Tempura Entree ($9.75) that came with miso soup, rice, and salad and Edamame ($1.50). 

The vegetable tempura pieces were somewhat crispy and did not taste too fresh. The pieces made my mouth feel dry. I tried dipping them into the tempura dipping sauce but that didn't seem to help. 

The miso soup did not seem like a miso soup to me. There were hardly any seaweed and tofu. The liquid leaned more toward the plain side.

The edamame was not seasoned, but it tasted fine. I was glad most of the edamame had a clean shell. When I say clean, I mean it had no suspicious dark patches due to having an expiration date of 3/25/2018. 

My friend had a chicken teriyaki dish that came with cabbage pieces. He thought the cabbage pieces were so bitter that the extra teriyaki sauce could not save them... or him.

I don't plan to come back. A wise friend once told me that the Tokyo Express near Powell is better than this one but I don't know if I can trust this opinion considering the low Yelp reviews at the other place.
author: Kristina M.

description:
It is a good casual lunch spot for picking up some quick takeout to eat back at my desk. I like that they have daily specials. The Monday chicken udon special for $7.99 is my jam. It comes with a huge order of udon with bbq chicken and a side salad. I usually request to have the chicken packaged separately from the soup/noodles because sometimes the chicken gets burnt and I don't like black stuff floating in my soup.

This restaurant is open later than other lunch spots and it is convenient since some days I can't take a break til later and I would rather avoid the lunch hour rush.
author: Sandy L.

description: I've eaten at this place on and off over the past few years.  The staff is friendly, the food mediocre.  The worst thing about this restaurant is that the staff cleans the tables with Windex throughout lunch.  The smell fills the whole restaurant.  So if you want sushi with a lot of ammonia, this is the place to go.  In addition, despite being open until 3:30, the staff removes the condiments from the tables at 1:00; so if you want soy sauce with your meal, you have to remove it from the plastic storage bin which can be found in the closed section of the restaurant.  If you are looking for mediocre sushi with a touch of window cleaner and no soy sauce, this is the place to get it but be sure to take it out.
author: Beth B.

description: Egregiously long wait for basic sushi and rude about it. Sushi was also terrible. Long lines at lunch. Not worth it. Much better places in area.
author: J. N.

description:
All my friends ridicule me for this but I love Tokyo Express. It's super close to my office, the prices are reasonable, and the quality is good. What more can you want?

My favorite thing to order is sushi combo #3. For only 13 dollars, you get 6 pieces of nigiri, 6 pieces of California roll, a salad, and miso soup. It's a steal.
author: Andrew C.

description: Ordered the Salmon & California roll combo through meal pal. Decent quality sushi, was readily available when I arrived. Solid location, good for groups, would definitely return!
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
Tokyo Express' Wednesday special (Caterpillar Rolls) are my favorite so I come back every week. The bill comes out to around ~$12 every time but it comes with crunchy california rolls, salad, and miso. 

The ambience is busy and really loud but I usually get my lunch to go instead of finding a seat. Everything comes out quickly, but not too fast. 

Overall a pretty good lunch spot. :-)
author: Cynthia M.

description: I had a Sushirrito from here as part of mealpal. It was decent but not something I would return for or seek out. The roll it self had chicken chunks in it that were a bit dry, I would have preferred it without chicken. There was also shrimp tempura in the roll as well but if they hadn't told me, I wouldn't have known.
author: Danielle B.

description: I came in for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon. It was pretty empty and the lady behind the counter wasn't too friendly. I ordered the chicken katsu to go and waited over 20 minutes. The lady in the front went to the back to check on my food and I could hear the cook in the back say he forgot to make my order. No apology. Food was not good. Over cooked, flavorless, greasy, dry chicken. Salad was sad looking and miso soup tasted like salty water. Never again.
author: Von P.

description:
I always get the same thing, salmon bento box. If I'm feeling greedy I'll add on some sushi. I always leave with my stomach full and money left in my pocket. Lots of comfortable seating, complementary hot tea, efficient service. Not sure why people dislike it so much. I've never had a bad experience and, my main concern, my salmon is never overcooked. 

Overall: Good value if your ask me.
author: Shoole S.

description:
Basic Sushi Lunch!

Tokyo Express will help you quench your sushi thirst at lunch time if you work in the area. I have tried them a few times and have been happy with the quality and service. The rolls are good, Teriyaki choices better and Udons even betterer!!

Honestly, I've never had a bad experience here, so I can't explain the low rating they have received.
author: Afshin A.

description:
This place is mediocre at best:

Food 2/5
Service 1/5
Price 2/5

Pretty overpriced crappy food. Only reason i ever come here is bc its near my office
author: Jesse J.

description: I like this chain store for a No-frill fast food Japanese restaurant.  Perfect for workday lunch.  Enjoy their chicken udon on a cold day.  The line could get a little long but the food is decent and most items are offered.
author: Fei W.

description: Fresh sashimi for a decent price. I got the sharashi bowl and a roll for $26. Soup and salad come with. Quick, good, and friendly folks. Hi lee recommend.
author: G S.

description:
Mediocre Japanese place with really good prices for the portion size. Their daily specials are pretty good deals though they don't actually change them daily. The daily special is usually an entree (like donburi or a roll) that comes with a side of miso soup and salad.

The lines can go out the door during weekday lunch times but it moves at a reasonable pace. Their chicken tends to be overcooked and blackened on the edges...
author: Lily L.

description:
The happy hour is the best time to come since it's a bit overpriced. The California roll tastes super spoiled like someone had it sitting in a car for a week in the sun or if the crab was sitting in the the sun for a month. I would not recommend getting the California roll. 
The poke salad is delicious but ask for non spicy if your not into the heat as its not listed that it's spicy. I don't think I would return to this place as there are better poke places that are better.
author: Star S.

description:
This place was surprisingly good. Came on a Wednesday with a coworker and got there around 1:40, the lady told us that happy hour was at 2. Sensing that our workload wasn't too much, we decided to wait. It said '40%' off but it was more like 30%. Either way I think we both saved about 8-9 bucks together which wasn't bad.

She got the tempura udon and for 5 dollars, it was good. I got the special Alaskan roll, shitake roll and spicy tuna roll. Not bad! For less than 10 bucks, I could def. go wronger (if it's a word) in the fidi area. There's a nice little outside area to wait at too if you'd like and the location is next to specialitys so the cookie smell might tempt you but hold out for this! For the cheap price, the quality is worth a second or even third visit when I'm going on my sushi cravings!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Even though it is tucked into a shallow location and in between skyscraper buildings, this Japanese sushi restaurant is convenient for lunch on the go or for dine in.  

I don't know why this place has such low ratings.  It's decent sushi rolls and udon bowls. A bit on the pricey side for average sushi, but they need to meet the rent and bills for the size and servers that they have, so it'll suffice.

Drop by here, if you work around here and craving for some sushi and sashimi satisfaction!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Why? Why does this place even exist? It's neither hip nor solid. It's...depressing. I'd rather skip lunch than eat here. And if you just need a place to talk - there are so many alternatives within a two-block radius.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I work right upstairs from this place, but I hadn't tried it until this week. My office ordered from lunch here the other day. It was a pretty large order (for 10 people), and they forgot a couple of items, but they quickly corrected the order once we came back. I'm noticing a lot of negative reviews concerning the service/cleanliness, but I can't comment on it because a co-worker pick it up.

The rolls that I ordered were pretty good. I tried both the Double Punch and the  Rock-N-Roll rolls. The fish was pretty nice quality, but the rolls were a bit too heavy on the tobiko for my liking. This place definitely isn't authentic Japanese, but it's decent for a lunch stop if you work around the area.
author: Cynthia M.

description: This place is near my office and is convenient for quick Japanese style lunches.  We have ordered the chicken katsu, beef udon with soba noodles and the Tokyo tower roll, all with brown rice.  I also have tried the salmon teriyaki and tempura udon. The tempura udon has a small serving of tempura so I wouldn't order this again.  The beef udon with soba noodles hits the spot on cold SF days. I like the fact that they serve brown rice with their entrees and sushi rolls.  Not a bad spot for decent Japanese food.
author: V B.

description: I ordered through mealpal.  Got a sushi burrito.   Unfortunately it was cooked fish burrito than sushi. There was no fresh sushi to be found anywhere inside.   All the fish (not even sure what kind of fish it was- texture was between a chicken and fish!! Strange!).   The taste was good.  But then again, sushi burrito should not be cooked fish through and through!!
author: Paul T.

description:
While Tokyo Express isn't the most gourmet or authentic Japanese place around, it's good for a fast meal and is particularly busy and popular with the lunch crowd. For those dining in, you order at the counter, are given a number, and seat yourself while you wait to be served.

I got an order of the spicy tuna roll, a side of rice, gyoza, and a bottle of tea, while my boyfriend got the chicken donburi, which came with a salad and miso soup. It was a lot of food for around twenty bucks, but while service was really fast - especially given the crowd - they really need a better organizational system here. The poor guy bringing around soup and salad had no idea what anyone ordered and had to ask every table what their orders were so he could know whether or not to give them soup and salad.

The sushi was actually pretty good, not too fishy, just the right amount of heat, but the gyoza were a bit different. This is the first place I've ever been to that tempuras their gyoza - while not my favorite way of making them, they were at least good and I'd probably order them again. My boyfriend likes the donburi here and though I didn't try it, I can at least say it was a big bowl with a lot of meat.

Again, it's not the best Japanese restaurant but it's good and you get a lot for your money. Plus, they're fast, if you don't have a lot of time. Decent lunch option if you're nearby.
author: Angela M.

description:
Chicken Katsu Bento Box

Where's the Katsu sauce? Oh, its on the table....weird....
Chicken-golden crisp exterior, relatively moist meat and with some traces of flavor

Turn around on food is really quick and they provide free tea and water to the right of the cashiers. Dine in meals come with a small salad and soup. Both were adequate but nothing different about their versions. 

The line can be intense during the lunch rush so please be aware. 

Overall Thoughts

A little puzzled by the long lines but I guess it's a convenient location for people
author: Eddie W.

description:
I work right next door, so it's really convenient. Two of the stars are probably for convenience, to be honest. The sushi is fine. It's nothing to write home about, but it satisfies a craving for it when I don't want to walk very far or pay very much.

The salad that you "get" is really not necessary. I wish they'd just nix it. It's like a few pieces of iceberg with some thousand island dumped on the top piece. Stop it. No one likes that.

Everyone is pretty friendly, albeit a bit confused. Whenever I order pickup, they're never completely sure if I paid or not, and I have to let them know. Also, the bus boy frequently tries to give away those "salads," but I kind of understand his reasoning for trying to give those away.
author: Sam D.

description: I love this place! For the price point, it's great. I usually get the chicken teriyaki donburi (under $10 for a good sized meal, can't go wrong!) but have also gotten the sushi before and it's been pretty good. Perfect spot for a quick, delicious and affordable lunch.
author: Kristina B.

description:
I recommend the Daily Special! It's all I've ever got here. They usually have a chicken or pork katsu special, plus a sushi special, which is what I get. It's generally two rolls for $10 and you also get the salad and miso soup. 

Order at the counter, then sit down with your number and they bring it around to you.

Bonus free tea always! :)
author: MaryKate M.

description:
If you're a local, I can see why you'd never want to eat here. However, if you're a tired and weary business traveler who has an office within a few feet of here - it's a solid place for a quick lunch. 

However, with some top-notch Japanese spots within a few blocks of here, I understand the lower reviews. Tokyo Express is just average and a more generic version of the higher-rated spots in the area. 

It's fast, convenient to the few high rises on this block, and you always know what you're going to get: piping hot udon; mediocre, but fresh sushi; and decent teriyaki. 

Free hot green tea!
author: Mark M.

description: My go-to place for an in-and-out, quick, acceptable, affordable lunch. Love the udon noodle. Fried pork is over cooked though.
author: Anya C.

description:
Although this place looks like a super fast food Japanese restaurant, the food actually tastes okay! I guess you can't really go wrong with veggie rolls (Got the vegetable combo) for lunch. The tempuras and side salads were not bad either.

My only wish is that they would have miso soup without the bonito so that the vegetarians could have some too.

Verdict - this place is okay for a quick bite~
author: Jade F.

description:
Quick Utilitarian Update:

While I still give all the noodle soups here top marks for taste and affordability.  I have to deduct a star.  Why?  Because their sushi has taken a nose dive.  It has always just been ok (with surprisingly yummy rice) and a bit over priced.  I was willing to over look this for the convenience to my office when I am craving sushi like crazy.  

Unfortunately the last 2 times I have ordered raw fish here the portion size has shrunk to a completely unacceptable level. The fish on my nigiri was 1.5inches by 1inch and very thin.  Yup, I broke out the ruler.

I guess I only recommend the noodle soups here now.
author: Susan C.

description: I needed a quick sushi fix and I was just left disappointed after spending $17 on the sushi deluxe special for lunch.  This is San Francisco - get it together!
author: Jenice M.

description: I almost ordered sushi here the other day, as I am attending a class at UC Berkeley extension and there simply aren't many options.  I noticed that things looked a little unclean, so I peeked over the counter where the sushi is prepared and it was covered with flies... two flies were even mating, it was absolutely disgusting. I will be reporting this to the health department immediately.  Avoid at all costs.
author: N T.

description: After being spoiled by Japan, nothing ever comes close, but for lunch I came here with my boss. Quick service and ordered combo 1 which came with soup, salad, a roll and 2 nigiri options. Filling for lunch and fish didn't taste bad. Not bad for a quick stop but won't come out of my way for.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This was another place I visited on a weekly basis simply because they were across street from my work, had very cheap food ($6.59 for a mountain of chicken teriyaki w/ rice), and very fast service.  

I think most people rate this place with low marks because it's always crowded and their food is slightly better than average.  I usually came in here either before the rush at 11:30am or after at 1:30pm.  So seating was never an issue for me.  There's been numerous times where I would order my food and it would arrive at my table 2 mins later.  It doesn't get better than that, especially during lunch hour.  

I don't order sushi that often so I can't rate them, but they looked very good on their menu.  I usually ordered 3 things: the Chicken Teriyaki Bento (6.59), their Nabeyaki Udon (8.29, sometimes 6.99 as a daily special), and their Tonkatsudon with a sunny side up egg (7.59).  Each are very good and could match the quality of any sit down Japanese restaurant.  The Nabeyaki Udon is loaded  with grilled chicken, seafood, and veggies, and so far, is the best I had from any Japanese eatery, simply because not many places put that much stuff in their Nabeyaki Udon like they do.

Overall, great place if you need a quick and satisfying lunch, as long as you don't go during peak hours.
author: Rodney H.

description:
I used to go here often, as it is close to work.  The food is OK, but what really galls me is their policy of closing off half of the restaurant tables at about 1:00  -- placing SECTION CLOSED -- signs as each table as soon as people leave and cramming late-lunch diners into the other half, so that every table, crammed close together, is filled.  I think they do this so they can start refilling soy sauce bottles and so on, for their convenience, and for the inconvenience of their customers. 

I will still go there sometimes, but am always annoyed by this.  In fact, I have even had people serve me there, then later come over and ask me to move, as they decided to close it after I was seated.
author: Jeff A.

description: Went a few weeks ago again.  I always order the chicken teriyaki with tempura on the side.  The chicken is sometimes overcooked.  When ordering to-go, the soup and salad is still included!
author: C G.

description: I had lunch here today with my friend, he had the Beef Teryiaki Bento Box and I had the Chicken Teryiaki Box.  It was OK.  Not great, just OK.  The teriyaki sauce was lacking in flavor, the tempura dipping sauce and the Miso Soup also lacked flavor.  I've had better.   It'll do for a quick lunch.
author: David S.

description: I order lunch to pick-up at least 3 days of a week from this restaurant. Their fish is pretty fresh, servers are very friendly and fast. I usually get blossom chirashi or sushi&sashimi which are both fullfilling and great. I'd totally recommend them.
author: Bengü E.

description:
don't do it. not even for happy hour. 

I went and got their most expensive sushi roll during happy hour, so i spent about $8. figured how bad could it be... well, it could be BAD. very very BAD. It was bitter. i don't even want to think about what could make a tuna roll bitter. 

customer service - awful. the sushi chefs had the roll ready to go almost immediately. it took the other staff about 20 minutes to pack it up. people who ordered after me and ordered more were handed their orders sooner. it got so bad that at one point the sushi chefs started inquiring into where my order was. I mean its just ONE ROLL people. 

if you're craving sushi and don't want to spend more than about 10 bucks, then just walk over to Safeway and get it there. It's so much better there. 

have to go find something to get this taste out of my mouth....
author: Alana V.

description:
Manger SUCKS!

To the store manager at this location, please next time make sure you are clear with what you are offering on your menu...an additional side of SASHIMI with an entree does NOT mean it's ONLY Salmon! I've gone to location so many f'ng times and now you are telling me this? 

Please, change your sign as it isn't clear as DAY!
author: Laurence R.

description: Super convenient location & you get a lot for your money.  Of course it's not going to be as good as your typical sit down Japanese restaurant.  It's the FiDi afterall.  But I've never been disappointed with their food.  The bentos and udons/sobas are plentiful; the chicken they use isn't questionable and taste wise it ain't bad.  Way better than the other chain option in FiDi/SF...Kamakura!  Get there early to beat the lunch rush whether you're eating there or getting to go..or you can use GoPago and pass the line at the register just like I did last time!
author: Cat C.

description: I use to go here but then I found out they were over charging me during they're so called sushi happy hour. Dishonesty get you no where with me and on that note I'm done. On yes, they're food is "OK". You can eat it but its not mouth watering to say the least. Oh, and service could be a lot better (stop over charging customers!!)
author: Jermaine J.

description:
This location is really close to my office so it's convenient if you're near; definitely no good if you want to drive. I always call my order in and pick it up 5-10 minutes after. Take a look at the website but don't go to seamless to order for this location because it is not one of the locations with that capability. 

I give this place 4 stars because of the teriyaki chicken bento plus tempura for $8.40 after tax. You get miso soup and a small salad too! For a Financial District lunch under $10 this is one of my top picks! The chicken is tender boneless skinless thighs, soft white rice, crispy shrimp and veggie (sweet potato, broccoli, carrot) tempura. You can add tempura to any bento for just $1.15 more!

The sushi is pretty good and decently priced too, but I mainly hit this place up for a quick lunch bento.
author: Travis T.

description: I have been there many times. Had the nabe yaki udon, the seafood udon, and the teriyaki chicken. Nothing fancy, my go-to place for hot Japanese dishes around FiDi.
author: Kinder H.

description:
A friend and I went here for lunch while craving some sushi on a lunch break. One of the things we ordered was the Vegetable Gyoza. When the dish got to our table, we tolok a bite only to discover that there was meat inside. We called a server over and she looked confused. After going back behind the counter and speaking to her coworker she came back only to tell us that it was "imitation meat". The meat tasted like real, 100% MEAT so them lying was not cool. Who puts imitation meat into a veggie Gyoza?! Clearly they messed up.

The rolls were also not good. Everything tasted like it was mushed together in terms of flavor. Definitly not going back.
author: Bella S.

description: This food is dreadful!!! I orders Lemon Basil Chicken and there isn't a whisper of Basil in this dish atall!!! In fact it's Teriyaki Chicken!!! I'm very perturbed
author: Xavier K.

description: I ordered the fish bento box with tempura. It wasn't bad. Totally okay. I liked that the tea was free and  the restaurant was clean.
author: Rosie M.

description:
When I first saw the "Tokyo Express" signage on Spear St, I was uber confused because I couldn't see the entrance. I felt like the restaurant was hidden in some labyrinth, or it's on a secret 9 3/4 platform. And as a friend mentioned it's awesomeness, I became more frustrated and determined to find this mysterious entrance. After some treasure mapping with Google, I have finally located Tokyo Express. 

So, the food. The food is better than good. Umm... maybe it's from a sense of accomplishment of finding this place. But no, the food is good. So good that Tokyo Express has become my favorite lunch spot in the FiDi. And I even went there for my birthday lunch.  

Their sushi is okay; afterall, this is a FAST lunch joint. But their winners are the donburi and daily special of soba tempura. I LOVE LOVE LOVE their soba tempura, and it's about the only thing I get their now. Every time I walk in craving sushi, I get swayed over with their soba tempuras. It is that amazing. Their tempura is soft, yet crunchy. Slightly oily and battered with a sweet salt. It has the perfect texture upon dipping it in the sauce. I get this delicious goodness even though it leaves me in a carb comma afterwards. Yum.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Went for a late lunch with friends and I would not go back or recommend this place. There were 3 of us and our food was brought out very randomly.  

I ordered a samurai & spider roll and miso soup. Friends ordered a chicken entrée and a #4 special, which included spicy tuna roll.


Ordering was fine, then we waited...  1st, my friend's spicy tuna roll that came in a #4 special.  The guy who brought it out didn't seem to speak much English and asked my friend at least 4 times what she ordered, despite answering each time. Several minutes later, came a side salad, but it was given to the wrong person, no biggie.  Several minutes later, the chicken entrée.  Looked a bit dry, but the gal that ordered it drowned it siracha sauce, so no complaints from her.  Several minutes later, I get roll #1, not one that I ordered.   Instead of the $9 spider roll, I got a $5 Crunch California roll and the tempura in it, was burnt to a crisp.  I can believe they would serve it like that. Several minutes later, the samurai roll and finally several minutes after that, my miso soup.  About 2/3 the way through lunch a gal came by with 2 miso soups and 2 salads, neither of which were part of our order, but the lack of English skills on the servers part, we thought it best not to add to any confusion, since they seemed completely lost.  

All in all, very mediocre food.  The dressing on the salad was awful, the miso was not very good and was not that hot. Definitely won't be going back there again.
author: Joanna D.

description:
Food is fine to quite good.  

However, the carpets in the dining room are filthy and stained and the restrooms were pretty disgusting on my visit.  All of which makes you wonder what the kitchens are like.  Which is not a thought you want to be having in a place that serves raw fish.  

Advice to Tokyo Express: do yourselves a favor -- steam clean or replace those carpets and take more / regular care of the restrooms.  Sushi joints need to be spotless.
author: Chris R.

description: Great for lunch... Fast service... Owner always pay attention on customers, clean establishment, varieties of sushi to choose from, bento box selections and price is affordable
author: Dedy G.

description:
My co-worker and I decided to stop by the One Market food court for a quick bite after a meeting and decided on some Japanese food.

I ordered the chicken teriyaki bento with tempura.  It came with a iceberg lettuce salad with a thousand island type dressing which was not too Japanese tasting.  The chicken was a good-size portion and was decent.  The tempura, which consisted of a shrimp, broccoli, squash, and sweet potatoes, was ok. Could tell it wasn't freshly made since it was only lukewarm.  The large scoop of rice was good and hot.

Overall, it is a decent place for some quick Japanese food.  The food did come quickly, within 5 minutes after the order.  Obviously, they don't compare to other sit-down Japanese restaurants, but for a quick bite, it's ok.
author: Al L.

description:
Believe it or not, there aren't very many sushi spots around the Embarcadero area to choose from.  Most of them are either a far trek away from my office or just a little too darn pricey for my lunch pocket. Nestled, well actually "hidden", between two buildings to be exact... and you enter Tokyo Express. Despite it's camouflaged location, this Japanese joint gets lots of business from the area. Come 12pm and this spot has a line forming out the door. SO, w/ my hungry stomach & noticing their long lines (from passing through on other days) I decide to take my gal pal there a little early one Monday to see what all the fuss is about.

You walk inside and notice that the restaurant is actually pretty cute. OK so maybe looks aren't everything (besides it's only lunch on your work hour), but it IS cute none-the-less, clean, and presentable.  They have lots of pretty pink flowers inside and is cutely decorated w/ those Japanese silhouette coverings of some Oriental sort.

The food is really good. The Udon noodle soups are big and plentiful; comes with an assortment of crunchy Tempura shrimp and veggies.  They have the standard Bento box specials w/ your choice of beef, chicken, or salmon teriyaki and Tempura. Again, they serve generous portions.  Often times they change up their daily specials to have Miso soup and Salad go w/ their sushi rolls.  I usually opt for their Rainbow Roll, Dragon Roll, or today I had the Heavenly Roll which is Salmon w/ scallions and topped w/ Spicy Tuna.  It's fresh and yummy to my tummy; served w/ an additional 6 pieces of California Roll.  Delish! 

TIP: Really bad, but right next door is Specialty's. Not to say that Tokyo Express won't leave your stomach full and happy, but Specialty's ((ahem)) is just around the corner.  I'm JUST SAYING!!! =)
author: Joy A.

description: It's ok... Two stars because the food's normal. I've seen much better Japanese restaurants... It's not bad but don't expect super good either. It's always pretty busy on week days.
author: David L.

description:
So I literally JUST finished my Salmon Bento Box w/ 6 pc. California Roll.  I was reading reviews about this place while eating, probably wasn't a great idea.

I remember seeing this place two weeks ago while walking to the Rincon Center from my office and was like WOW this place must be amazing, it's packed! Then today when I didn't bring lunch again, I decided to stop here, (without checking yelp first, shame on me).

I was going to order Chicken Katsu Bento box at first but changed to Salmon Teriyaki (7.59 cu zit was a special, 7.99 normall) just cuz my throat isn't feeling very well so didn't want to make it worse.  The Salmon Teriyaki was the special of the day, it was 1 dollar more to add tempura, 2 dollars more for california rolls, and 3 dollars more for spicy tuna.'

I got here right at 12 and there was only one person in front of waiting with two cashiers.  From the moment i ordered my food til i got my food was about 2-3 minutes, SUPER fast service, but I guess it's cuz they were preparing for the rush.

I ordered to go, went back to my office and unpacked.  For the bento box, I had 3 pieces of salmon over cabbage, a scoop of rice, some salad, a cup of miso soup, and 6 pieces of sushi in a separate box.  The rice was okay, typical rice, not great not bad, the salmon was a BIT dry but not looking for 5 star quality from a to-go restaurant.  The soup was... interesting, i didn't really like it.  The teriyaki sauce on top of the salmon was good tho.  The sushi was mehh, they were really small, didn't have much of the "meat" in them and the avocado didn't look fresh at all.

The food was 'ite.  I wouldn't go again cuz I think Sorabol is a bit better in the quality and quaniity for roughly the same price for the same kind of food.

Overall the place deserves a 2.5 stars, I gave it 2 cuz I'm a tougher cookie to break.  But I do have to say that most reviewers are comparing this place to an authentic Japanese restaurant they have been to somewhere else somewhere else, which is stupid cuz this place caters to a completely different audience.  This place is located in Financial District, the food here, is about the same price as all the other "food court" food around the area.  How can you expect authenticity from a to-go place the word express in the name of the restaurant?  It's like going to Panda Express (note also has express in it) and complaining the food doesn't taste like the food they ate in Hong Kong.

This place serves it's purpose, fake Japanese food for people that have short lunches and can't go very far for better food.  All the restaurants around the location are made for the people in the office buildings surrounding it, they have to get the food out as quickly as possible cuz people just don't have time to wait.  So don't come here expecting some Benihana-like cooking performances and service, cuz that's not the purpose of this place.  If you're not from the area, I'm not sure why you would come here for the food, so don't.
author: Willis C.

description: I came here with some former colleagues for the first time in a long while last week.  I must say that their sushi had better quality that day and tasted much fresher then I remember in the past.  So, I'm raising to 3 stars and would not mind returning back when I'm in the area.  I usually get a nigiri combination (used to be Sushi Combo B, but now I think it's represented by a #).  It includes: 5 piece nigiri,  California roll pieces, miso soup, and I always sub for edamame instead of their salad.  I'm not a fan of their dressing with the grinded carrots.  There's a good amount of seating and a line during the lunch hour.  They move quickly with their orders and have good food service.  It's an A-OK lunch spot :)
author: Alvin J.

description: This place is okay except that they want to charge you too much for every single extra or substitute item. For instance if you order chicken udon and you want brown rice instead of udon they will charge you for the brown rice ....$2.25 !!  On top of that they give you very little chicken and they want $3 for extra chicken.  So a bowl of soup could cost 12 bucks!  They also don't keep forks at the tables anymore so you have to get up fetch one if you want to eat with a fork!!   Food is decent though.
author: Adam S.

description:
Tokyo Express is exactly what the name suggests - it's fast, it's functional, but don't expect mind-flowing cuisine. It's meant to serve professionals on quick lunch-breaks, not a relaxing, decadent dining experience. 

I always get their bento boxes - the regular bento varieties are served with speed and efficiency - the actual food though can be a bit on the greasy side for Japanese dishes. For example, all the teriyaki  bento boxes I've ever ordered were dripped with oil. The sushi is ... again, fine, though it takes a bit longer to. 

The whole place works like a fast-food place, as evidenced by the variety of apps tools they use for customers to place orders and pay. To be honest, it was fine for the first few days to eat Tokyo Express all the time. After a while, you would start to crave for higher-quality food.
author: Nancy L.

description: Best lunch spot in SF FIDI area. Really tasty, reasonably price & good portion. None of those super pretentious all natural food type of restaurant that charge $$$ for a salad. I had try most of their menu, my favs is the daily special sushi (everyday is different type), Udon & Chicken/Beef/Salmon Teriyaki Bento. Drawback: it can get really busy, long line to order. They do Seamless & phone order though, so you can pre-order the food and pick it up 5 minutes later. Tokyo Express catering has catered lunch for my company often, and they are absolutely amazing. The delivery always arrive on time and Sushi look fresh and appetizing. Definitely my go to catering restaurant, cheap and delicious. Perfect for any event.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I ordered a bento box.  It was ok, not great.  The teriyaki chicken and rice was basic, nothing special. The most notable item, and not in a good way, was the tempura.  I found the batter too thick and heavy, almost like something I'd expect if I ordered fish 'n chips at a british pub.  In any case, I prefer the tempura batter to be a little finer and the shrimp didn't taste fresh.

I'm sure I'll occasionally return because it's conveniently located near work, somewhat decent, and super quick.  I'll never suggest it to friends as a "good" lunch spot.
author: Lee T.

description: Ok, walking by today I saw the health score posted on the window...75!!!!!!!!  EWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWW!!  Also, there was a post-it note stuck on the score with "violations fixed on ___".  Um, wth??  Like some orange piece of post-it note is the official response?  Never coming back again unless I see the REAL score is at least in the high 90's!!!!!
author: Monica P.

description: We happened upon this place by accident when my brother had a meeting in the same building and we were hungry afterwards.  The location is perfect, decor elegant, service excellent, and the food...  Well, we ordered a light lunch from the counter and both loved our choices, which were delivered to our window table promptly.  My noodle soup was made vegan cheerfully (!) and was too large for one @ $6, and my brothers sushi was ample for $3!  Plus, no line for an early lunch (12n).  We complimented the staff when we left, which they accepted graciously.  Wonderful!
author: Naia N.

description:
I'm on the fence with "Express" restaurants. You shouldn't have high expectations from fast food joints.  And this sushi spot is just that - but...it's suprisingly decent!?!

It's usually pretty packed during the rush hour.  When you line up, be sure to know what you want.  Otherwise, you may hear some grumblings for taking your sweet time. If you need a few more minutes, stay to the side until you figure out what you want before standing in line.

I've tried a few of their sushis and all were decent. Like I said, it's not the BEST, but then again, we're talking about fast food. Giving it 3 stars for its quick service, fairly cheap  prices, and convenient location in the heart of downtown SF.
author: Diana M.

description:
If there were an option, I would have given this place no star. Service is horrible, food is so so. It's run by bunch of punks who are not even Japanese!

I came here with a friend for lunch today. I placed my order, and so did my friend. My friend thought I place a tempura soba, and informed the cashier that she would like to have the same order as mine. When the cashier repeated the order, I realized it was wrong and requested her to correct one order. Same price, just different order. She "indirectly" insisted that we kept our order but I requested to help change it. She rolled her eyes, stomped into the kitchen, and orders were placed. 

I wasn't too happy with her whole attitude and mentioned to my friend that we should talk to the manager. Okay, we found our seat and waited for our food to come. When the waiter gave us our salad, I asked who the manager is, NOT "I want to speak with the manager". He told us who the manager is and left. I didn't complain or say anything else. Our food arrived and we were enjoying our food. Next thing we knew, a manager came out and asked why we wanted to speak with him. I told him that I didn't ask to speak with him, i just asked the waiter who the manager is. Since he was there, I told him about the little incident.

He then literally yelled at me and my friend that it was our fault for placing the wrong orders and he saw the whole thing. He added that they had to throw away the order that the cook just made because of our mistake. I then said you could have told me that instead of yelling and giving attitude, and we would have kept the order. No yelling or attitude necessary. He looked like he was about to eat us. A Young punk with doo doo hair color is a manager??? 

Then, the cashier came to ask me if I complained about her, and I told her about the whole story - basically, I only asked who the manager is but her co-worker went in to tell the manager that I wanted to speak with him. She explained about how the kitchen staff was upset when order was wrong. I kindly explained to her that she could have told us upfront instead of huffing and puffing, we would have totally understood. I advised her to not do the same thing to other customers. A simple explanation will take care of issues. 

I admitted that it was our fault for placing the order wrong. However, the way the manager handled the issue was completely wrong. You don't yell at customers, you could have just explained it. We, the customers, don't know how your system and kitchen work, idiot!!!

The cashier handed me the phone number of the owner (David). If the attitude of the manager is like that, I am almost sure there is no point of calling the owner. 

I will never go back to this place! There are many Japanese restaurants in FiDi.
author: S L.

description:
This is a worthy lunch option in the financial district if you get a craving for some Japanese food.  The menu is extensive and the prices are more than reasonable for both sushi and other items.

What is nice about their main dishes is that they are served with a lot of vegetables, salad and soup.  Some other Japanese lunch spots in the area are stingy with veggies and flood the food with sauce.

Highly recommend the veggie udon and chicken donburi.  Both are huge portions.  They do a good job with the sauce on the donburi and it comes with a nice fried egg on top.

Like some other people wrote call ahead during lunch.  The line to order can be out the door.
author: Fay M.

description:
Their udon soup is acceptable, but certainly not great; barely good.  Their other miso soup is really disappointing.  Their bento boxes are at best two stars; they are not made with care, and frankly are just mediocre.  They have plenty of indoor seating, and their line during the lunch rush moves very quickly, and they satisfy their niche (Japanese lunch food) better than other places nearby, and they are priced well / inexpensively.

This review is part of a series on lunch places near my office.
author: Zachary R.

description:
Yet another FiDi Japanese joint that serves teriyaki with a side of rice, in a bento box, donburi-style or in udon soup.  I suppose it makes the menu look big while keeping the food stock simple.  The sides/appetizers are pretty skank, but the udon was tolerable.  You can do A LOT worse in the FiDi for lunch unfortunately...

Salad: I hate salads that use large chunks of iceberg lettuce (the Tito of the lettuce family) and pale tomatoes.  The creamy dressing with orange colored shavings of something was nice, but disappeared after I ate the one cucumber slice on top.

Gyoza: Potsticker style, no.  Deep fried with a light tempura, yes.  Never had a dumpling in tempura before so appreciated the new experience.  Learned that I prefer traditional potsticker-style though.

Nabe-Yaki Udon: Basically an everything udon.  The broth is savory and salty with a hint of seaweed.  The noodles are decent, though a tad too soft.  Fish cake, plain tofu, shrimp and spinach taste like you'd expect.  The deep fried tofu skin is a nice touch since it absorbs a ton of broth.  The teriyaki chicken had a good texture and light flavoring, could use some more teriyaki marinade.  There was imitation crab (a la California roll) that got stringy and slimy for a very unpleasant texture experience.  There was half a hard boiled tea egg which added much excitement compared to traditional hard boiled eggs.
author: Adam B.

description:
Hell hath no fury like a sansei scorned...BANZAI!...BANZAI!

The Japanese side of me wants to perform hara-kiri on myself with a dull blade for the mediocre mix of flavors that contaminated my palate, but the American side of me wants to go all postal. OK, that's not me...but I would give the cook a lingering glare and a case of small-mouth for the disappointment I had there today.

Hiding (as it should be) in the courtyard of a cluster of non-descript buildings, this looks at first like a welcoming presence in a Lee's Deli-dominated white-collar world. It certainly buzzes with activity with the wait staff a mere blur as they speed by the throngs of office lemmings sourly indifferent to each other.

I went predictable today with the $5.99 Chicken Teriyaki Bento Box. I ordered it to go, so it was packaged in a symphony of styrofoam, enough landfill to satisfy a family of cockroaches and their in-laws after the big one hits. Syrupy sauce ladled liberally over generic chicken pieces. Lukewarm tempura with an oddly resilient texture. Salad that looks like it was stolen from Lee's around the corner. But the miso broth was nice and warm.

Dare I give it one star. No, I won't. A colleague told me the California rolls are tasty, so I must give it another chance. It is after all, the food of my peeps. Well, at least it pretends to be, and sushi-eaters must support their own. But what's with the name? Despite their speed, I was not feeling the 'express' vibe as I was leaning against a column as if giving birth to it. Tokyo Express sounds like an Andrew Lloyd Webber roller skating musical reset in a Toyota plant.

FOOD - 2 stars...barely...bento go boom
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...certainly looks like a typical Japanese eatery
SERVICE - 3 stars...dressed for express
TOTAL - 2 stars...desperate for Japanese in this area, are you?...here, take the sword...you'll need it
author: Ed U.

description: They've recently been hit with some Health Code violations and scored a 79.  They did post a note alongside the score that they've resolved the violations, but eeek, me thinks not.
author: Ivan D.

description: This place is to Japanese food what Taco Bell is to Mexican food. Eat here if and only if all other options have been exhausted.
author: John H.

description:
It is OK. Coming from the south bay this place is sub-par but for the area it is alright. I had the heavenly roll and I am not a fan. It had a really fishy taste to it and it was overly spicy. The California roll was, good even if it is a standard roll. 

The pricing is fair. What I do not like is how you are rushed to order and the people who work there do not give you recommendations which is frustrating for a newcomer (yelp was not very descriptive for the sushi rolls)
author: Jessica N.

description:
Really good! For Fidi, the price is competitive, and it's good. I'm sold!!!

Yea...my tempura was cold and my miso soup had WAY too much seaweed, but it was under $10 so I'm really very happy with me meal. 

The Bento box is your best bet. If you're really hungry get some nigiri on the side and it'll be about $12-13, and you'll have gotten a good sized meal. I'm definitely fond of here.
author: Cory D.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch and it was PACKED. It's like fast food japanese. I ordered edamame and seaweed salad. For $6. Food comes out fast and portions are pretty good. Service is crazy because it is busy so they can't be very attentive. Will return most likely. 

The location is very cute in a nice courtyard!
author: Adrienne C.

description:
For many years, this was one of my go-to lunch spots in the downtown area. So, now that I'm back working in the area, I went back to the Tokyo Express for lunch a couple of times recently. Sad to say, things seem to have slipped significantly in recent times. Very disappointing -- this last time, I left without finishing my lunch.

My experience in the past was of tasty, generously-portioned Japanese food & sushi, and friendly service. The portions are still generous -- on the enormous size, in fact, but the lunch dishes now appear to be rushed out with no attention to detail and, most concerningly, the meat quality seems a bit suspect to me. I recently had a Pork Katsu, and I found it unappetizing and hard to digest. Today's Chicken Teriyaki was gristly and unfinishable. 

I'll be giving Tokyo Express a pass for a while. Hopefully, things will improve -- but in the meantime, there are lots of other superior Japanese restaurants in the area.
author: donal c.

description:
Debated between 2 or 3 stars; regardless is going to be a negative review.  Highly doubt that there is anyone Japanese in the kitchen.  I guess if you are looking for a quick and cheap fix of Japanese food for lunch downtown, Tokyo Express might satisfy you, but don't be looking for any quality Japanese food here.  Problem with these kind of places is that they don't even do the white rice right!  Pickles and a good quality bowl of white rice could satisfy me, but they cannot even do that.  

What is more amazing is that there is usually a line out of the door during the lunch time rush.  Why?  If you suck up $5 more, you can go across the street to Ozumo and have a quality lunch.  With that said, the line did illustrates the need for quality inexpensive Japanese lunch.  In Japan, you can get a decent 600 Yen lunch set ($5), yet people always say food in Japan is expensive.
author: トモ T.

description: Real talk: I don't actually like sushi.  Seafood creeps me out.  But this place has solid vegetarian options, which I am super appreciative of.  Now I can at least fake being a real person.
author: Nora S.

description: Let me start this by saying, no, there's no way you're going to be coming here on a hot Saturday night date. In fact, I probably wouldn't eat here at all, since it's incredibly noisy and crowded, and the food can take quite a long time unless you order something really simple. But as a lunch take-out spot, this place has all that you'd want--decent sushi at a reasonable price (honestly, Whole Foods is about the same price or maybe even more expensive and not as tasty), and while the udon can be a little overcooked the broth tends to be rather good. I haven't been disappointed by the food here, although I don't set my expectations terribly  high. The fish in the sushi tastes fresh and they even have my beloved ume shiso kyu rolls. Good enough for a weekly stop to satisfy my sushi urges at a decent price.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Wow....I guess I should've checked Yelp before I went to Tokyo Express...  After seeing the line at Bistro Burger, my friend and I decided to get Japanese food.

I was surprised by how busy Tokyo Express was - I'd never been before, but, as Ed U. said, it is tucked away in a little corner.  I love bento boxes, so when I saw the bento box on the menu, I was SO excited.  I LOVE bento boxes - reminds me of my childhood - and I ordered the chicken teriyaki bento box.  

I thought the food was okay - the chicken was a bit dry and bland - but generally edible.  The tempura was decent (it's a little tough to screw up deep fried food!), though the iceberg lettuce salad was pretty disappointing (so many Japanese salads have that yummy, delicious dressings).  I must admit, this isn't really like the classic bento boxes that I've had before; the Tokyo Express version is definitely a pale imitation.

My bento box wasn't too expensive - about $8 - but I think your money might be better spent elsewhere.

Also, the place was so crowded that my friend and I were like vultures, hovering, looking for a spot to sit.  I hate the lunch-time seating stress....
author: Wendy L.

description:
Completely unseasoned sushi rice.
No wasabi smear under the sushi fish.
Miso soup - no tofu cubes and no wakame/seaweed at all.
Tea - pretty much lukewarm water.
AND a short curly hair pulled from out of my california roll.  I'm not lying or trying to be mean here, but there it was and that's when I got up and left.
I've eaten here before and it was average at best before.
I don't think they expect their customers to know the difference between good and bad sushi, so, well, that's why it's bad.
I should have suspected any sushi place with the word, 'express' isn't bound for greatness.
Ugh.  A little curly hair in my california roll?  Come on, man.  Get it together.  I wouldn't have noticed it, but I tend to eat the insides of sushi rolls first and just picking at it I pull out a hair.  Sure, hair can fall into food prepared for the masses, but ugh.  Not good.
author: Kev M.

description: This is a decent sushi/bento lunch spot. Definitely the most reasonable price for sushi on all the surrounding blocks. It can get really crowded between 11:45-1:00 so my bet is to order it to go since their take out service is generally quick. Lunch here runs roughly 9-12 bucks which isn't too bad at all for all the food you get. I rolls aren't impressive but they aren't shabby. Best value is to go for one of the lunch specials like the teriyaki/katsu chicken which comes with miso soup and salad. (Extra for tempura..why)? in all 3-3.5 stars for par quality at a below par fidi price point.
author: Norris T.

description:
This place is the embodiment of average. It seems like a work lunch favorite of a lot of people in the area, and the two strengths of this place are that it's fast and filling. I don't think anyone comes here for the high quality sushi, so I'm not even going to bother going into details. It's a get in, get out kind of place, and the food isn't terrible. Sometimes, that's all you need.

Also, maybe I'm just not used to SF prices yet but $10 for donburi is considered cheap...? Please, someone take me back to Manpuku in Berkeley where I can get fresh rolls for $3.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I usually come for the deluxe bento at lunch. You get quite a bit of food for a decent price. They have a wide selection of rolls but from what I have seen the quality is mediocre. 

This place tends to be really crowded and can get loud during the lunch rush. 

Finally with such a large menu that is only really found on the wall and many different options that can be hard to pronounce(and hard for the cashier to understand), the cashiers can have a hard time taking orders.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Ordered Tonkatsu Bento ($8.95)
Even if the bento box was $3, not worth it. The pork was over cooked and half a centimeter thick, so it was like chewing cardboard. I might pay $2 since there was a lot of rice and I was homeless.
author: Jim L.

description:
Having to eat in the FIDI this is one location that actually provides quantity and good quality Japanese food at a reasonable price ~$10/order.  I think its justified after a month of eating here that I finally complete my review of this lunch place.  I am glad I didn't check Yelp before going otherwise it might have turned me away from this hidden gem.  I have ordered the chicken donburi, salmon teriyaki bento with tempura and beef teriyaki.  While all are solid, I have to say the beef teriyaki was slightly on the dry side.  Please note I have not tried any of the rolls or sashimi.

Salmon teriyaki bento is my favorite so far.  I must say, this place does not make it dry but the teriyaki glaze may be slightly excessive.  However, the taste is solid as is the rice.  Comes with the salad and miso soup, both which are really typical.  For an extra $1.50 you get shrimp and veggie tempura.  Sometimes the tempura comes out slightly cool and not piping hot, but needless to say, still tastes fresh.

I have no complaints about the lines or lunch crowds, maybe because I come here before the noon peaktime and long lines out the door.  I like that this place has self serve tea, means you don't end up waiting around for a busboy to come assist.  

Clean cute establishment.  I will be back again and again to get my bento, I am sure. Maybe someday I will venture over to their rolls.  Comparing to most establishments in FIDI, I would give this place 5 stars but since I don't just eat in FIDI..I find 4 stars to be an honest review.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
Stopped in after 1.5 years of avoiding it.  Gut instinct was right. Not sure why this place gets packed. (Cost? Convenience?)

Ordered a chicken teriyaki bento box with vegetable tempura. The very chewy chicken had no flavor, they provided a very small amount of tempura sauce, and the tempura was the worst: twice fried (thrice?) rubbery thickly battered pieces of vegetable - mostly carrot and yam with a single piece of broccoli that was lost in the awful batter.  The rice was undercooked and the "salad" had some strange pinkish dressing on it that reminded me of pepto bismol meets my cat's hairball goo. ewwww.  I didn't even bother with the miso.  

Interestingly, a woman walked out with a bag of her left overs, which she proceeded to throw into the garbage basket outside the restaurant.  Oddly, the non-tasty chicken left an aftertaste. hmmmm...

Lesson: You get what you pay for (usually).
author: King K.

description:
Went here for lunch yesterday because I was craving sushi and a coworker said she's been before.

Sushi was very boring.  For $8, you get California roll and 4 nigiri.  It wasn't too bad but also was not good.  I suppose I lucked out because my coworker ordered the special and she couldn't eat the albacore that came with cuz it was very fishy.  At least mine was edible.

Won't be going back there again.
author: Cindy C.

description:
This is your average Japanese fast food restaurant. Come here for a quick and filling lunch. Come here if you have a sudden Japanese food craving in the middle of the day. Don't come here if you want high quality sushi. Considering the area, I'd say it's reasonably priced. You do get quite a lot of food for under $10, and the service is really fast even when the place is packed!

The vegetable udon ($6.59) is pretty tasty and filling. They included a pretty generous amount of vegetables and tofu. I wish they cut the vegetables and tofu smaller though. My coworkers ordered bento entrees ($6.59+) which looked delicious and were surprisingly big. I do not recommend the rolls. Average at best and on the small side. The California roll ($4.25) had so much mayonnaise. What's up with that?
author: Waz W.

description: They messed up my order major then the person after me ordered the same thing and they charged them $5 dollars less for the same order. The service is slow and the people don't really understand English.
author: Dane S.

description:
I work close to Tokyo Express and have ordered from them twice for business receptions and have been seriously disappointed twice.  The first time I ordered from them, they got my order wrong and shorted me a large sushi platter.  They were able to make the missing platter within a couple of hours but I still had to go back to pick it up, severely compressing my time frame to get other things ready for the reception.  

The second time I ordered from them they got the date of the order wrong.  They were supposed to deliver the sushi platters between 3:30 - 4:00 and I called them at 3:45 to get an e.t.a. for delivery and they told me they didn't have an order for that day.  They had an order for the next day.  My reception started at 5:30 and I had an hour and forty five minutes to get food for 66 people.  The manager had NO customer service skills.  When I asked him, "What am I going to do?"  he responded, "I don't know", barely apologized and didn't offer any compensation for totally effing up my order.  I know what I'm going to do...I'M NEVER GOING TO ORDER FROM TOKYO EXPRESS AGAIN.  EVER.

Marginal sushi, poor customer service and completely sub par business operations.
author: Fabiana S.

description: Great simple sushi made to order quickly for a reasonable price. Great place to swing by and grab a quick lunch if you don't have a lot of time
author: Nick B.

description:
The only place within a 5-block radius in which I'll order raw fish.  The few times I've been here it's been fresh; I hear from coworkers that I've just gotten lucky but so far so good.

I work really close to a place called Sushi Fantastic.  If I ever order raw fish from a restaurant with such a name, I deserve whatever the repercussions.
author: Gary D.

description:
I decided to give this place another shot because it was close by and it was very cold.

This place is still awful.  I ordered a Beef don this time, but all it is is their teriyaki beef on top of rice.  They should not call any of their items on their menu with a "don" because that could be confused for anything else:  Katsudon is not tonkatsu on rice.  Beef don could be mistaken for Gyudon.  They should just call it "Teriyaki beef with rice".

The beef was very tough and overcooked and had no flavor to it.  The teriyaki sauce was very bland too.  Where did they get this sauce??
author: Jason W.

description: Did not realize there was a place behind the gate and trees in front of it. My coworker introduced me to this cute little joint and we got the sushi combo A for lunch. It's neat where you order at the cashier, but they bring the food out to you. So we had a nice, quick lunch, but didn't feel rushed. The soup and salad was normal. The sushi was ok, it was a bit warmer than I liked it, but the fish seemed pretty fresh.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I'm a little in the middle on this review because there are some positives that would make this place a 4 star but there are some not so positives that brings this place closer to a 3.  

First, the sushi and quality of the fish is actually decent.  I think it helps that this place gets so busy that they go through a lot of fish each day.  As a result, the fish is generally fresh.  Second, the portions are also a decent size, but then again, I eat a lot so the portion size might be a lot to some.  Third, the prices are decent given that this is sushi in the financial district.  I don't know if there is really any other place you can go to.  

As for the negatives, my only complaints are that it gets really busy during lunch time and it's weird eating sushi fast food service style.  If you go, make sure you get there early so that you don't spend most of your lunch break in line.  It's also odd that you wait in a line to order, like McDonald's, and then go wait at a table for your food to be brought out to you.  So it's odd when you pay, do you tip not knowing how the service will be or do you wait until you're done?  

Overall, decent place, nothing spectacular but good given the area.
author: Patrick L.

description:
This is one of my favorite lunch places in the Financial District. It's also one of the best ways to get a big, inexpensive lunch in the neighborhood. I've only eaten their vegetarian food, but all of their vegetable sushi is great, and the vegetarian udon is a cheap and incredibly delicious meal all on its own. My favorite roll from here is the crunch tofu, which is amazing, enormous, and costs $3.75 -- I order it with extra avocado (50 cents).

The line does get long, but it moves really fast, and you can order ahead online or by phone and just go pick up your lunch.
author: Alexa F.

description: I am still puzzled why this place is packed, except for the rather cheap prices.  The chicken donburi I had was almost unedible.  The chicken was super dry and didn't have a half decent teriyaki sauce -- tasted like cardboard almost.  I'll give it to them that they are speedy, and bring the food out to you in minutes.  I don't know how long everything has been pre-cooked for, but it sure didn't taste fresh.  The salad was OK.  The miso soup was OK.  I rather pay a few more bucks, and get some better japanese food.  This is like the Mcdonald's of japanese food almost! Except they do bring out the food to you.  The unlimited tea is cool, but I can get tea anywhere.  Fish is never really fresh.  Big portions, but bland! I've been here a few times and have never been impressed... The chicken donburi pushed me to my last!
author: Tramy V.

description: Had a lunch here with some coworkers. When they mean express , they really mean express. you order your food ,pay then sit down. my order came out in about 2 mintues. The Chicken katsu seemed to be prepared ahead of time. thin and dry. The tempura was thick with a hard batter. FYI no tea was served and you had to get it yourself.
author: Michael T.

description:
Okay,

So the food here isn't amazing and while I haven't had the fish here in quite some time I can recommend some awesome vegetarian food.

-The Tofu Crunch Roll: Yummy tempura tofu wrapped with rice and seaweed. You can't lose with this one
-Avokyu Roll: Cucumber and Avocado together and it feels so right
-Asparagus Roll: Fresh and good and hits the spot 

They also have about 5 other vegetarian rolls which is awesome because it can be hard to find a good variety of tasty vegetarian sushi. 

Like everyone else said get there around 11:45-11:55 to beat the huge lunch rush and save yourself a seat!
author: Nerd A.

description:
This is my current destination for cheap Japanese food in the financial district. First of all, if you're expecting good quality sushi for a cheap price in the financial district, dream on ... So set your expectations accordingly for this place.

This location is a little hard to find since ithe entrance is deep inside the center of the block. The food quality is below Kitaro's out in the Outer Richmond district, but not as bad as the places in malls like Rincon Center. This places does get packed during lunch with people waiting for takeout and you see people ordering the raw sushi combos so you know it is decent for the financial district.

I usually come here for the bento boxes and combos of the day and they are price around 7-10 dollars plus tax. The bentos come with the usual miso soup, salad, and rice. The miso actually has a good amount of tofu in it. The salad is acceptable, but it lacks any tomatoes. 

I usually get the pork ton katsu and it's not bad and doesn't taste like it's been sitting there for awhile. If you want add tempura to your order, add over a dollar more to your order.

If you want a cheap bento box for lunch on a workday, this is a good place to hit. if you're craving some really good sushi, look elsewhere. You will only find average quality sushi here.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Wooooo Wooooo Woooooo (thats the sound of police sirens in case you didnt get it)

Me panting "Officer.... I've been robbed!"
Officer "Calm down son, tell me what happened"
Me still catching my breath "Someone sto...stol....someone stole my salmon!"

http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/Z-rsvl65p7XyiZi1ruNfyw/l

Davids bottom line-  Where the hells the rest of my salmon teriyaki?  
Please be on the lookout for a man/woman weilding a saucey piece of fish last seen in the SOMA area.  
(fish in picture appear larger than than they really are)
author: David L.

description: I really wanted to like this place, but when I went today, they'd just changed their menu and jack up their prices.  They added an appetizer section to their menu.  Their Nabeyaki Udon as a Special on Mondays were $7.59.  It has now been taken off the Specials menu and cost like $10.  Their 6 pieces of California Roll was also taken off the menu and you are force to either order 4 pieces or 8 pieces.   Service was okay, but they'd hired this new guy to clean up the table that only does half the job.  He collects the dirty dishes, but he never, and I mean never, wipes the table clean.  I have to ask the food delivery gal twice before he will come back to wipe the table.  I hope the owner talks to this guy and straighten him out about the cleaniness.  The only reason I come here is because it's close to my office.
author: Angela T.

description:
I like Japanese food, so I decided to take a friend here for lunch.  Unfortunately, if anyone Japanese was in the kitchen, they weren't paying attention.  They're using Japanese recipes, but they're not serving Japanese food.  

Take their simplest, top-of-the-menu item, a deluxe bento box.  The vegetables were cut a bit thick, and were therefore hard in the center.  The beef was, shall we say, chewy.  It didn't seem worth $9 per person to me.  If it weren't for the wonderful company, I would have eaten elsewhere, and next time I'll look for something more enjoyable.  

The line was fast, but so what?  It will go even faster without me in it.
author: David D.

description: Average food with nothing to write home about.  It is always busy with the lunch crowd and I like the self-service tea and water so we don't have to wait for someone to get or refill your tea cup.
author: Annie L.

description:
NASTY.  WRONG.  RIP-OFF.  SCARY.  These are a few of the words that come to mind when thinking about Tokyo Express.
The fact that this place is always packed with people is one of the great mysteries of the world.  Get within 10 feet of the door and the smell of chlorine and bad fish slaps you across the face.  It's a smell that the body immediately recognizes as dangerous.  Patrons must overcome the body's natural fight-or-flight smell reaction to push on toward the counter and place an order with the bored teenaged cashier.  And if you thought the smell was bad, try taking a bite of the food.  Cover your eyes and throw a dart at the menu--WHATEVER YOU CHOOSE will be bad.  
Fish never tasted this wrong.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description: A generic and cheap lunch spot, very popular with the lunch crowd. It's not the best Japanese food you can get downtown (for example, Sanraku at the Metreon is better), but it meets the need of most office workers.
author: Luis C.

description:
I can't stand being begged for tips. Sure you order at the counter and then they bring the food out to your table, but does that count as tip worthy service? If you miss the tip jar up front, you won't miss the signs posted on every table that say "Thank you for your generous gratuity"... not that I'm opposed to tipping for good service, I just would prefer to do it on my own terms!

I eat here about once a week and always go for the bento box lunch deal. The tonkatsu, chicken katsu and various teriyakis are good scores and you can add a side of tempura for about a buck more. There's free green tea on a self-serve basis at the counter and the food usually comes out of the kitchen licketty-split! I have never tried the sushi here, so I can't vouch for its quality but what I've seen looks decent. 

Tokyo Express....thank me for my generous 3 stars!
author: Nate R.

description:
If walking by you might miss this spot.Despite being always crowded most of time I have gone by,well I  wasn't to happy with this place when I finally ate here.I almost cried.

Teriyaki Express is much better.
author: Dani D.

description: Sometimes I'm craving sushi for lunch, and I want something fast, easy, and something I can just order and take to-go. This is perfect for that.
author: Alison B.

description: Decent food, but watch out if you get sashimi! Their sushi "chef" (if you can call him that) has significantly shortchanged me on multiple occasions.  Today he gave me 12 pcs when I paid for 20, and when I complained, only gave me 16.  Fortunately I caught it again, and finally got what I paid for.  It shouldn't be such a major hassle to get what you ordered.
author: Kevin O.

description:
This is a convenient place to eat so I come here a lot.  It gets really crowded if you go right at noon so try to get there early.  I've had better food, but this isn't bad.  I started out with bento boxes and got tired of them, so I started getting udon.  The udon is pretty tasty.  But the last time I ordered chicken udon, it was really burnt chicken in the soup and so my soup had a lot of burnt bits in it.  Kind of gross.  Sushi is ok, but not the best.  

A bento box note - if they ask you if you want tempura and you say yes, they'll charge you an extra dollar.  Last time I didn't realize that what they do is substitute the california rolls in the bento with the tempura so that kind of sucked.  You pay more money but don't get the california rolls.
author: Stacey C.

description: This isn't the best place for sushi but their Bentos and Udon are pretty decent. I work right around the corner and find myself coming here during my Japanese food craves. The is probably the best Japanese place within the area, and seems to have quite a few fans. Lunch time, lines are always out the door and tables are packed. The pricing is pretty decent for the area, but like I said. Don't order the Sushi or Sashimi. It's not fresh. Just stick to the Bentos and the yummy Udon!
author: Natasha S.

description:
At sushi places like this where I'm just going for take out, I don't have a lot of expectations to be met. Furthermore, I don't order raw fish. With my weak stomach it's just not a good idea. I also don't order bento boxes, but that's because I rarely order them anyhow. Same with tempura.

So I keep it simple. I order some rolls. Recently I ordered these:

Philly Roll (smoked salmon, no way my stomach will react)
Ume Shiso Maki (pickled plum with shiso leaves)
Kampyo Maki (marinated gourd)

I liked them all. Excect for the extreme carb coma, no complaints here. I paid less than $12 for three rolls (2 were veggie) and I was not hungry for a loooong time after. I've also gotten their futomaki. Same resulting tiredness and satiated belly.

There's a line during peak lunch hours. If you don't order the specials your food will take time to come out--I assume because their specials are pre-made in large quantities. But for what it is (quick basic Japanese food) you could do worse in the area. Just remember to choose wisely.
author: Amy N.

description:
No.....
No. No. No. No. No. 

It gets one star because the to-go service is really fast. I had one good meal here, and things quickly deteriorated from there. Things that bug me about the bento box: 

*the salad is watery because they don't bother drying the lettuce after washing it and because there's barely any dressing 
*the miso is waaaaay too salty 
*they fail to put California roll in your bento box if you order to go (even if you don't get tempura) and 
*when they ask you if you want to order shrimp tempura (for an extra charge), sometimes they'll just put the veggie tempura WITHOUT any shrimp

I really tried to like this place, and came here a couple of times, hoping they would get their act together and come up with a nice meal like they did the first time. 

Convenient location and quick service mean very little when the food sketchy.
author: Jay P.

description: I am not surprised the Health Score for this place is 79 (I did not know this when I went). A few days ago I went here with some co-workers for lunch. Two of us ordered Chicken with rice and one of ordered sushi rolls. Our chicken was cold...Not just room temp cold, but cold. I got a refund and left and got food some where else. They were quick about the refund...sort of like it happened often. The guy that stayed to eat his sushi rolls fund a hair in one of the rolls... GROSS. I would not recommend this place.
author: Karen P.

description:
Not bad, not bad. It's not the best sushi ever, and it's a pretty generic atmosphere, but you can get a big lunch bento for $10 including rice, a few pieces of sushi, a few pieces of tempura, a decent amount of teriyaki chicken, salad and miso soup. Well not really salad, more like some iceberg lettuce with some of that red vinegary sauce on it. Not very nutritious, but sorta tasty. I'm actually not even really into the bento thing. But, you know, it's there if you want it. I usually just get a couple of rolls.

Anyway, decent, pretty fresh sushi and passable udon. I can't really complain; it's a reasonably priced lunch option a block from my office which makes it kind of a staple. Friendly, efficient service too. Even in the face of massive lunch crowds.
author: Megan W.

description:
Are you:

A.  A sushi lover?
B.  A cheap bastard?

If you answered yes to part B only, then Tokyo Express is for you.  The quality of this place is pretty hit or miss.  Mostly miss.  I think they have two passable rolls - the Heaven Roll and the Kamikaze (both parts of daily lunch specials).  If you don't like those, you probably won't like anything else.  I still eat here (partially because lunch sucks anyway and partially because I fall into part B), but I wouldn't feel good about recommending it.  Also, after reading some other reviews, I checked to see if they were overcharging my credit card, which they were.  So, the sushi is sort of below average and they're kind of sneaky bastards.  It still gets two stars from me because I still eat there for some reason and I have yet to get amoebic dysentery after a meal.
author: Sunil A.

description:
This is a quick and convenient place for lunch.  It's the place where you can find me and my friend sharing and venting the week's events.  
It's by no means great food, but it's simple and it works for me.  We get our food quick so we can spend the rest of the hour talking.

I always get either the chicken or pork katsu bento box with tempura.  
The chicken teriyaki dish with rice is not bad either.  Don't bother with the salad that comes with the meal, but the miso soup isn't bad.  Of course, the better Japanese restaurants beat out this place without question, but for $8 it does it's job.

All in all, don't expect a lot from this Financial District restaurant.  The name says it all.  It's an express lunch, not gourmet.

BTW, don't just chuck your receipt, check it for discounts on your next meal.
author: Denise M.

description:
Went here for lunch with a friend today.

We both ordered bento boxes, salmon & chicken. $7.99, not bad. 

Wanna know why it's so cheap though? My tempura vegetables were still hard, and the teriyaki sauce was watered down. Talk about cutting down costs.

The portions were OK. Two stars because it was quick, and their sushi rolls at Stonestown are awesome.

Probably won't come back though.
author: Sharon V.

description:
*UPDATE*

Ordered for a huge meeting the office was hosting.  Ordered the day before multiple sushi platters, teriyaki combo trays, salad & tempura.  The order came right on time as promised & the presentation was amazing!  I highly recommend you cater thru them especially in the FiDi.  All the guests were loving it, nice change up from sammich platters.

I always go at an off-time if I want a quick Japanese fix to go or to eat there.  The bentos arent bad, but eat it there.  For a quick pick up lunch I always go with my usual Blossom Chirashi.  Beats going to Oiishi.......
author: Stephanie D.

description:
